170370808.review:
Overview:
Don't Starve Together (DST) is an engaging multiplayer survival game developed by Klei Entertainment. It builds upon the original Don't Starve solo experience by introducing cooperative gameplay, allowing players to work together (or against each other) to survive in a whimsically dark and challenging world.

Gameplay:
The gameplay of DST revolves around exploration, gathering resources, crafting items, and managing hunger, sanity, and health meters. Players can choose from a variety of quirky characters, each with unique abilities and drawbacks, adding depth to team dynamics. The game emphasizes strategy and cooperation, as surviving the harsh environment requires teamwork to build shelters, hunt for food, fend off monsters, and explore the mysterious lands.

Overall Impression:
Don't Starve Together stands out as a compelling multiplayer survival experience that blends challenging gameplay with distinctive visuals and a richly atmospheric world. Whether playing with friends or strangers, the game encourages collaboration and emergent storytelling, offering a deep and rewarding experience for players who enjoy exploration, resource management, and cooperative gameplay.

169910992.review:
I love this game. There is nothing else quite like Don't Starve. I could sit here for an hour just writing about all the things this game does really well, and all the things that make the experience unique. So you might find yourself asking why this review is negative. What could possibly be so bad that it essentially voids all this good will? 

This games net-code is so horrendously garbage, perhaps the worst I've ever encountered in a game like this, that playing with friends is an objectively worse experience than playing singleplayer. To make matters worse, the only reason this distinction can be made between multiplayer and singleplayer, is because an extremely talented member of the community made a mod that actually fixes the input delay and desync issues you'd experience when playing ON A LOCAL SERVER BY YOURSELF. To elaborate just a little for the sake of clarity, this game runs a server for the overworld, and a separate server for the underground/caves. This leads to horrible performance issues and network delay no matter what computer you have. These issues are understood to be a fixture of the game by the community and have been since its release. There is nothing you can do about this. Your build does not matter, your internet does not matter, these issues are permanent and universal and the devs have done NOTHING to fix them. Installing the mod "Don't Starve: Alone" (which is a hilarious appeal to how absurd this issue is especially given the nature of the game and its working title.) will fix these issues when playing by yourself, which is a completely valid and enjoyable way to interact with the game if that's what you are looking for. But Don't Starve is a stressful and unforgiving game that relies so heavily on time management (the kind of experience that is immensely more fun with a friend) that this issue is almost unforgivable for me. Playing with the mod and then switching to multiplayer means not only having to get use to massive amounts of input delay, it also means you're taking unavoidable damage, it means every singe action you take and make for your entire play-through feels horrid, and this is a game where the player is meant to die and die and die before you even learn that there are specific actions and routes you're meant to take to progress effectively in new runs. (things that require hundreds of hours of game knowledge to pull off and take advantage of). 

I could write another 3 paragraphs about why this is such a problem and why it bothers me so much, but if I took the time to do that, it would be more time than they've spent in development trying to fix the netcode issues since the games release. Horrible horrible stupid issue for a game like this to have. I love this game and understand its highly positive reviews, but I'm frankly also perplexed this isn't brought up more. It makes it so hard to get friends into the game and makes a learning curve that is shaped like Mt Kilimanjaro somehow even less accessible to new players. If you are willing to play alone exclusively, and are willing to put hundreds and hundreds of hours to see 60% of the content, then yes, buy this game. But most players will spend their first 50 hours repeatedly dying to new things and repeating the first 5% of content over and over, not even beginning to understand some of the needlessly arbitrary ways you interact with the game's world, unless you watch hours and hours of guides giving you explicit information and explaining things you most likely never would have pieced together yourself. 

I love this game, but find myself mentally exhausted at the thought of even trying to pick it up most the time. And the experience is so poor with other people I don't even bother anymore.

171044076.review:
The Missed Potential of Don’t Starve Together: A Tale of Frustration and Lost Opportunities

[h2]The Potential of Don’t Starve Together[/h2]

[i]Don't Starve Together[/i] was launched with high expectations. The core mechanics of the original game lent themselves beautifully to a multiplayer setting. Players could work together to gather resources, build bases, fend off seasonal challenges, and face the game's unique blend of horrors. However, while the game received periodic updates, it never saw the expansive development that fans hoped for.

[h2]Unrealized Development Opportunities[/h2]

Klei had an opportunity to create a game that could rival other popular multiplayer survival games. The foundation was there: a devoted fanbase, a well-established game world, and mechanics that could easily be expanded upon. These expansions could have kept the game fresh and engaging for years. Advanced modding support, regular content updates, and deeper storylines could have transformed [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] into a cornerstone of the multiplayer survival genre.

[h2]Why Focusing on One Game Makes Sense[/h2]

Investing heavily in one successful game, rather than spreading resources across multiple projects, can lead to a more engaged and loyal community. Players are more likely to rally behind a game that receives consistent updates, new content, and developer support. This approach has several benefits:

[b]Stronger Community[/b]: A single, well-supported game can foster a strong and active community. Players feel a sense of ownership and investment in a game that continues to evolve and improve.
[b]Brand Loyalty[/b]: Consistently supporting and expanding one game can build brand loyalty. Players who see ongoing value in their purchase are more likely to support the developer in future endeavors.
[b]Economies of Scale[/b]: Investing in one game allows for economies of scale in development, marketing, and support. Resources can be used more efficiently, leading to better overall returns.

[h2]Examples of Developers Who Made Similar Mistakes[/h2]

Several developers have made the mistake of abandoning successful games in favor of new projects, often with disappointing results:

[b]Stunlock Studios[/b]: Known for [i]Bloodline Champions[/i], Stunlock Studios let the game stagnate, then shifted focus to new games. They developed [i]Battlerite[/i], a spiritual successor to [i]Bloodline Champions[/i], but again failed to maintain long-term support, leaving fans disillusioned.
[b]Digital Extremes[/b]: While [i]Warframe[/i] eventually became a huge success, Digital Extremes initially struggled with inconsistent support for their other titles like [i]Dark Sector[/i] and [i]The Darkness II[/i]. Only after committing to [i]Warframe[/i] did they find sustained success.

[h2]The Tarnished Multiplayer Experience[/h2]

One significant issue plaguing [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] is the poor multiplayer experience. The game's multiplayer mode was meant to enhance the survival experience through cooperative play, but instead, it has introduced several problems that detract from the game's original charm. Players often find themselves in lobbies where experienced veterans clear the hardest content in mere seconds. Meanwhile, new or less experienced players are still harvesting their second tree, leading to a disjointed and unbalanced gameplay experience.

This disparity ruins the once challenging aspect of the game and makes a true cooperative experience impossible. Instead of working together to overcome obstacles, players are often not even on the same screen most of the time. This lack of coordination and shared purpose fundamentally undermines the cooperative nature of [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] and turns what should be a team effort into a fragmented and frustrating experience.

[h2]Financial Implications and Cost Analysis[/h2]

From a financial perspective, the decision to underdevelop [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] appears misguided. The game has a loyal player base willing to purchase expansions, cosmetic items, and other forms of downloadable content. A well-supported and continually updated [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] could have ensured a steady revenue stream. Instead, Klei has missed out on this potential by not capitalizing on the game's initial success.

Let's break down the costs and missed opportunities:

[b]Development Costs[/b]: Developing [i]Don't Starve[/i] likely cost around $1.5 million, considering it was an indie project with a small team. Adding the multiplayer component for [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] might have added another $1 million.
[b]Server Costs[/b]: Maintaining multiplayer servers typically costs around $500,000 annually. Over the past ten years, this amounts to $5 million.
[b]Investments in Other Projects[/b]: [i]Griftlands[/i] likely cost around $5 million to develop, while [i]Oxygen Not Included[/i] might have cost around $10 million. [i]Hot Lava[/i] and other projects could add another $5 million to the total.
[b]Total Potential Investment in DST[/b]: If Klei had redirected even a portion of these funds into [i]Don't Starve Together[/i], let's say $10 million, it could have led to substantial content updates and server improvements.

[h2]Comparing Player Numbers[/h2]

Comparing the player numbers between Klei's games and other popular cooperative games highlights the missed opportunity:

[i]Don't Starve Together[/i]: Peaked at 20,000 concurrent players in 2016, now averaging around 5,000 to 6,000.
[i]Oxygen Not Included[/i]: Peaked at around 18,000 concurrent players.
[i]Griftlands[/i]: Peaked at around 5,000 concurrent players.
[i]Hot Lava[/i]: Peaked at around 3,000 concurrent players.

Comparing to other big cooperative multiplayer games:

[i]Terraria[/i]: Peaked at 486,918 concurrent players in 2020.
[i]Minecraft[/i]: Millions of concurrent players across various platforms.
[i]ARK: Survival Evolved[/i]: Peaked at 157,400 concurrent players in 2020.

[h2]The Merger and Future Prospects[/h2]

In early 2021, Klei announced that Tencent, the Chinese tech giant, had acquired a majority stake in the company. This merger has raised questions and concerns within the community. Some fans hoped that the infusion of resources from Tencent would lead to renewed investment in [i]Don't Starve Together[/i]. However, others feared that this corporate shift would further divert Klei's attention away from their beloved franchises.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]

[i]Don't Starve Together[/i] represents a significant missed opportunity for Klei Entertainment. The game had all the ingredients to become a staple of the multiplayer survival genre. Instead, it has languished without the support it deserves, to the frustration and disappointment of its loyal fans. By neglecting [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] in favor of other projects, Klei has not only lost potential revenue but also eroded the goodwill of their community.

The investments in other games have not yielded the expected returns, and the funds that could have been allocated to [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] are now depleted. The game's development is now essentially in "life support" mode, with little hope for significant updates or improvements. Trust and willingness from investors to reinvest in [i]Don't Starve Together[/i] are at an all-time low, making it unlikely that the game will see the revitalization it desperately needs. Thus, prospective buyers should be aware that the game's future looks bleak, and their money might be better spent on more actively supported cooperative alternatives.

169545585.review: Every time I die in this game I remind myself that i'm still learning. But then I die the same way when I respawn. This game also had a crossover with the game that is better than Minecraft: Terraria. When I see the eye bone when i'm out exploring, I feel as I'm being brought closer to heaven. When I play Walter and I get hit I loose my precious sanity and get pulled closer to hell. When I play as Webber and get killed by my spider companions I feel as if my parents are more disappointed in me. When I play as Wilson and he gets another stage of beard growth, I feel as I'm laying in a tranquil, calm forest. As I close my eyes and start to drift off to sleep I sleep too long and I get killed by darkness. When I play as Willow and I loose a little bit of sanity I make a tiny, insignificant fire. When I get my sanity back I take a look at the forest fire and realize I've disappointed my idol, Smokey the Bear. When I unravel all my clothes for more spools I realize that I'm poor, but at least I got a new plant friend to keep me company. When I play as Woodie and it becomes a full moon I stare at glommer taunting me in my goose form. When I play as WX-78 and I eat spoiled food I feel as I am helping the environment by eating the food no one else will. Overall, this game is awesome, but when playing you will need a professional player with you, a Youtube tutorial, or the wiki open. The Beard is the best one to follow along with. Very good game, 8.91876375153784766278737716548958528948659563927592658264283947402757663752920586652652/10.

My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get Dont Starve to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

168347499.review:
[h3]Shared struggles are a great way of cementing your friendship, or convert you to impromptu cannibalism..[/h3]
The games title is basically a great pitch for the entire game, you run around in a slightly spooky twilight zone with your quirky friends trying to find enough calories to pass around before the monsters find you and drain your life and sanity in equal measure. 

DST revolves around the same great loop of exploration, resource management and crafting that was the hallmark of Don’t Starve, only now you can do it with a bunch of equally deranged pals, and it is so much better with friends.. The intricate dynamic that emerges from a spontaneous division of labor (sprung straight from Marx's manifesto), combined with the creepy victorian atmosphere and gorgeous hand drawn art works wonders balancing out the ever diminishing levels of hunger, sanity and health. The entourage of characters, all with their own powers and weaknesses, enables you to gather a dream team of quirky individuals and start building an utopia in the otherwise dreary wilderness.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3276704701
Now, if a buyer should know one thing about this game is that the learning curve is quite steep, and since time passes in game with seasons that quickly can turn a chill vacation into a nutrient starved death trap one must be aware of a few key mechanics to even survive the first year into the game. The reward for mastering this game however is, in my humble opinion, oh so sweet.

In the end this is a game I keep returning to, and not only for the daily login gift that is an economy in itself, but for the emerging narrative that is so vibrant. There are so many hilarious ways to fail in this game and each and every one of them leads to a great story. So try to remember that when you get harassed to death by murderous frogs and tentacles trying to get enough paper to write your final will..

Recommended, but be aware that it can be quite daunting to get into, especially if you have never encountered the first installment of the game..

171918276.review:
Don't Starve Together
It's fun alone also in a team. It's a top down survival game with comic graphics
and mod support. Which is really great and if the game is too difficult for you, there are mods for that too.
At the beginning the learning curve is a bit difficult but that also makes the game interesting.

167487456.review:
the survival is cool, random generation gives and affects choices in different ways, and there's seemingly never any object or mechanic you can exploit fully. it's pretty fun learning slowly, and making desperate choices as resources dwindle or events change everything

however, the combat is an equally big part of the game. and instead of being knowledge-based, it is entirely skill-based. it's very punishing, and no matter the enemy, one can walk away unharmed OR lose all health and healing.

survival is what i came to the game for, but the very different gameplay of the combat is still mandatory for a large half of the game.

166520266.review: "Don't Starve Together" is a captivating cooperative survival game set in a whimsically eerie world. With charmingly macabre visuals and challenging gameplay, it invites players to work together to brave the wilderness, gather resources, and fend off threats. Its emphasis on emergent gameplay ensures each playthrough is unique and memorable, making it a must-play for fans of survival and cooperative gaming alike.

168959082.review:
I started playing this game with a friend. I died within the first 10 minutes by eating a food item. I lost my items (they burned up for some reason) and I spend about 15 minutes as a ghost looking around to find a way to revive myself. I couldn't start a new character on the server, only play my dead character. Online research didn't really help, as most of the items needed were things you need to do when alive, or find something in the world that I just didn't find. I quit the gate. 

I have never played Don't Starve, and I feel this game expects you to have done so. It doesn't explain anything to you, and expects you to do your own online research. I don't feel like doing that. I got this game for €5 on sale, and am asking for a refund.

171849184.review:
Unforgiving, but very rewarding.
Great mechanics and well thought-out game.

171746738.review:
A survival simulator where every day becomes a challenge.  Atmospheric graphics, a well-designed world and a lot of unexpected situations that keep you in suspense.. The cooperative mode is fun and at the same time makes you think before doing something.  The game constantly gives new impressions, although sometimes it can become a bit monotonous.  A great choice for those who like to test their survival skills with friends.  I recommend!

Симулятор виживання, де кожен день стає викликом. Атмосферна графіка, продуманий світ і безліч несподіваних ситуацій, які тримають у напрузі.. Кооперативний режим веселий і водночас змушує добре подумати, перш ніж щось робити. Гра постійно дарує нові враження, хоча іноді може стати трохи одноманітною. В цілому, чудовий вибір для тих, хто хоче випробувати свої навички виживання сам чи разом з друзями. Рекомендую!
